column4: I have a 32 GB SSD and 500 GB HD In my laptop, what is the best way to install ubuntu?
define "best"   and maybe folks can help further
I want to use SSD to load my system and maybe some applications, but HDD for everything else
Probably just system loaded by SSD for now
than I guess just install to the SSD, and setup the HDD as /home
How do I do that?
I anticipate I will have at least 50 GB of applications
so I don't know if that is a good setup
when it comes time to partition (during the installation process), ask to do, wait what?
50GB of apps?  what apps?  are these games?
yes games and development tools
like Quartus
do you see why I am concerned?
well, I don't know.  Maybe maybe you could have all the app files mounted to the HDD?
I do, but 50GB is a HUGE amount of apps
unless its games, so... it's just unexpected
And my system is UEFI...
I'm in for a trat...
I bought a nice shiny ultrabook that used the SSD as a cache to 500 GB HD
maybe dual boot, one for regular use, and one for all those games.
But linux doesn't support that
Is there a way I can just put the kernel and boot stuff on the SSD?
maybe by mounting /boot to ssd, but I don't think that will garner you much performance benefit
in fact, the HDD might be faster for that...
